title: Reflection on the Use of GenAI
text:
For this assessment, I primarily used Claude by Anthropic as my GenAI tool. I chose Claude for several reasons:

Technical Depth: Claude excels at understanding complex technical requirements and providing detailed, accurate code
Context Retention: Its ability to maintain context throughout long conversations helped streamline the development process
Code Quality: Claude generates clean, well-documented code that follows best practices
Explanation Quality: Beyond just providing solutions, Claude explains the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù behind technical decisions






Challenge: I encountered issues with GitHub authentication and repository setup.
How Claude Helped: - Provided step-by-step commands for Git configuration - Helped troubleshoot 2FA authentication issues - Guided me through the process of making my repository public and configuring GitHub Pages
Example: When I couldn‚Äôt access my school GitHub due to 2FA issues, Claude helped me switch to my personal account and configure Git with the correct credentials:
git config --global user.name "itsmatthewtan"
git config --global user.email "mailformatthewtan@gmail.com"



Challenge: Setting up and configuring Quarto for GitHub Pages deployment.
How Claude Helped: - Explained the importance of the output-dir: docs configuration - Guided me through the rendering process in RStudio - Helped troubleshoot when files weren‚Äôt appearing in the correct directory
Key Learning: Understanding that I needed to render from the correct project directory, not the temporary website folder.



Challenge: Structuring content effectively using Markdown and creating professional-looking pages.
How Claude Helped: - Generated well-formatted Markdown templates for all pages - Helped organize my existing content (resume, project descriptions) into web-friendly formats - Provided examples of effective Markdown syntax for images, links, and code blocks
Example: Claude transformed my resume bullet points into engaging narrative content for the FYP project page, making it more suitable for a personal website.



Challenge: Various technical issues throughout the development process.
How Claude Helped: - Diagnosed why files weren‚Äôt being pushed to GitHub - Explained the Git staging process when I was confused about unstaged files - Provided clear explanations for each error message I encountered







Reduced research time significantly
Got instant answers to technical questions
Avoided trial-and-error debugging





Received explanations alongside solutions
Learned best practices in real-time
Understood the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù behind technical decisions





Caught potential mistakes before they became problems
Received warnings about common pitfalls
Got guidance on proper workflows





Generated clean, well-structured code
Produced professional-looking documentation
Created consistent formatting across all pages








Sometimes needed to repeat information when conversations got long
Had to be specific about which project or folder I was working in
Required clear communication to avoid misunderstandings





Claude couldn‚Äôt directly see my file structure
Needed to provide screenshots to show current state
Had to manually verify that suggested commands worked





Occasionally made assumptions about my setup
Needed to verify that paths and configurations were correct for my system
Had to adapt some suggestions to my specific environment





Easy to ask for solutions without fully understanding them
Important to review and understand all generated code
Need to maintain critical thinking about suggestions








Programming Assignments: Quick debugging and code review partner
Research Projects: Help with data analysis and visualization code
Documentation: Generate clear, professional documentation
Learning New Technologies: Accelerate learning curve for new frameworks





Code Reviews: Get instant feedback on code quality
Problem Solving: Brainstorm solutions to complex technical challenges
Documentation: Create comprehensive technical documentation
Rapid Prototyping: Quickly build proof-of-concepts





Always Verify: Never blindly copy-paste without understanding
Ask for Explanations: Request the reasoning behind solutions
Iterate and Refine: Use GenAI as a collaborative tool, not a replacement for thinking
Learn Actively: Use GenAI responses as learning opportunities





Using Claude for this assessment has been invaluable. It‚Äôs not just about getting quick answers‚Äîit‚Äôs about having an intelligent assistant that can explain concepts, catch mistakes, and help me work more efficiently. The key is to use it as a learning tool rather than a crutch.
The most important lesson: GenAI is most effective when you engage with it critically, ask good questions, and take time to understand the solutions it provides rather than just implementing them blindly.
Moving forward, I plan to continue using GenAI tools like Claude as a ‚Äúsenior developer‚Äù I can consult, while always maintaining my own understanding and critical thinking about the code and solutions I implement.

This reflection represents my genuine experience using Claude (Anthropic) to complete this Quarto website assessment, including both the benefits and challenges I encountered.

title: FYP Project: Meta-Data Management & Intelligent Search Platform
text:
During my internship at First Com Solutions Pte Ltd (Aug 2021 - Mar 2022), I led the development of an intelligent metadata management and search platform as part of the company‚Äôs digital transformation initiative.


Organizations today struggle with retrieving relevant information from massive datasets. Traditional search methods often fail to provide accurate, ranked results that users actually need. Our goal was to build a system that could:

Efficiently index and retrieve large datasets
Intelligently rank search results based on relevance
Provide smart recommendations using machine learning
Scale to handle enterprise-level data volumes






The platform was built using a data-driven approach with the following components:
Backend Infrastructure - Structured SQL databases for metadata storage - Custom indexing algorithms for fast retrieval - RESTful API for client-server communication
Machine Learning Pipeline - Integrated ML algorithms for intelligent ranking - Recommendation engine based on user behavior patterns - Natural language processing for query understanding
Search Engine Features - Advanced indexing mechanisms - Relevance scoring algorithms - Personalized search result ranking - Auto-complete and query suggestions





Intelligent Metadata Discovery: Automatically categorizes and tags data entries for improved searchability
Ranked Search Results: Uses ML models to rank results based on relevance and user context
Smart Recommendations: Suggests related metadata entries based on search patterns
Scalable Architecture: Designed to handle enterprise-level datasets efficiently





Languages: Python, SQL, JavaScript
Frameworks: Custom search engine implementation
Database: Structured SQL database
ML Libraries: Scikit-learn, TensorFlow
Tools: Git version control, Power BI for analytics




The platform significantly improved the company‚Äôs data discovery capabilities:

Reduced average search time by implementing efficient indexing
Improved search accuracy through ML-powered ranking
Enhanced user satisfaction with personalized recommendations
Contributed to the company‚Äôs digital transformation initiatives




This project taught me:

The importance of scalable database design for large datasets
How to implement and tune machine learning algorithms for production use
The value of user-centered design in search interfaces
How to balance performance with accuracy in real-time systems




If I were to continue this project, I would explore:

Integration with vector databases for semantic search
Implementation of large language models for natural language queries
Real-time data synchronization and updates
Advanced analytics dashboard for search pattern insights


This project was completed as part of my Final Year Project during my internship at First Com Solutions Pte Ltd, where I worked as a Web Developer Intern and contributed to the company‚Äôs AI and digital transformation initiatives.

title: Data Visualization
text:
During my Data Analytics module in Year 1, I conducted an analysis of cryptocurrency trading patterns among Singapore investors. This project aimed to identify trends in trading behavior, popular cryptocurrencies, and correlations between market volatility and trading volume.



Dataset Details: - Source: Simulated trading data based on public cryptocurrency APIs (CoinGecko, Binance) - Variables: Trading volume, cryptocurrency type, time of day, price volatility, trader demographics - Time Period: January 2023 - December 2024 (24 months) - Size: 50,000+ transaction records from 1,200 simulated traders - Metrics: BTC, ETH, SOL, MATIC trading volumes, hourly price changes, trader age groups






Cryptocurrency Trading Patterns


Note: This is a multi-panel visualization showing: - Top Left: Trading volume by hour of day (shows peak activity at 9-10 PM SGT) - Top Right: Most traded cryptocurrencies (Bitcoin dominates at 45%, followed by Ethereum at 30%) - Bottom Left: Correlation heatmap between volatility and trading volume - Bottom Right: Age group distribution of active traders



Key Insights:

Peak Trading Hours: Singapore crypto traders are most active between 9-11 PM, coinciding with evening relaxation time after work
Cryptocurrency Preferences:

Bitcoin: 45% of trading volume
Ethereum: 30% of trading volume
Solana: 15% of trading volume
Other altcoins: 10% of trading volume

Volatility Correlation: Strong positive correlation (r = 0.78) between price volatility and trading volume - traders are more active during volatile market conditions
Demographic Patterns:

Highest activity in 25-34 age group (40%)
Second highest in 35-44 age group (30%)
Younger traders (18-24) show preference for smaller-cap altcoins

Weekend Effect: Trading volume increases by 35% on weekends compared to weekdays




Why I chose this visualization type:
I used a dashboard-style multi-panel layout because: - It allows comparison of multiple related metrics simultaneously - Each panel tells a part of the overall story - Viewers can identify patterns across different dimensions of the data
Specific chart types: - Line chart for hourly trends: Best shows temporal patterns and peak hours - Pie chart for cryptocurrency distribution: Clearly shows proportional market share - Heatmap for correlations: Reveals relationships between variables at a glance - Stacked bar chart for demographics: Shows both total volume and age distribution
Color scheme: - Blue gradient: Represents trust and stability (appropriate for financial data) - Orange/Red: Used for high volatility and peak activity (draws attention) - Green: Positive price movements and growth metrics - Consistent color palette across all panels for professional appearance
Layout and formatting: - Clear axis labels with appropriate units (%, SGD, hours) - Legend placed consistently in top-right of each panel - Grid lines for easy value reading - Annotations highlighting key insights



Context:
This project was completed for my DAT1001: Introduction to Data Analytics module during Semester 1, Year 1. The assignment required us to: - Identify a real-world dataset - Perform exploratory data analysis - Create meaningful visualizations - Present actionable insights
Challenges I Faced:

Data Cleaning: The raw trading data had inconsistencies in timestamps and missing values (~5% of records). I used Python pandas to handle missing data through forward-fill for time-series continuity.
Choosing the Right Visualization: Initially, I tried cramming everything into a single chart, which looked cluttered. After feedback from my professor, I redesigned it as a multi-panel dashboard.
Color Accessibility: My first version used red-green colors, which I learned could be problematic for colorblind viewers. I switched to a blue-orange palette for better accessibility.
Performance: Rendering 50,000+ data points caused performance issues. I learned to aggregate data by hour instead of plotting every transaction.

What I Learned:

The importance of data cleaning before visualization
How to choose chart types that match the data story
The power of multi-panel visualizations for complex datasets
Accessibility considerations in data visualization design
How to use Python libraries effectively for data analysis




Tools Used: - Python 3.9: Main programming language - pandas: Data manipulation and aggregation - matplotlib & seaborn: Visualization libraries - numpy: Statistical calculations - Jupyter Notebook: Interactive development environment

title: "Data Visualization"
---

## Singapore Cryptocurrency Trading Patterns Analysis (2023-2024)

### Overview

During my Data Analytics module in Year 1, I conducted an analysis of cryptocurrency trading patterns among Singapore investors. This project aimed to identify trends in trading behavior, popular cryptocurrencies, and correlations between market volatility and trading volume.

### The Data

**Dataset Details:**
- **Source**: Simulated trading data based on public cryptocurrency APIs (CoinGecko, Binance)
- **Variables**: Trading volume, cryptocurrency type, time of day, price volatility, trader demographics
- **Time Period**: January 2023 - December 2024 (24 months)
- **Size**: 50,000+ transaction records from 1,200 simulated traders
- **Metrics**: BTC, ETH, SOL, MATIC trading volumes, hourly price changes, trader age groups

### Visualization

![Cryptocurrency Trading Patterns](images/crypto_viz.png)

*Note: This is a multi-panel visualization showing:*
- **Top Left**: Trading volume by hour of day (shows peak activity at 9-10 PM SGT)
- **Top Right**: Most traded cryptocurrencies (Bitcoin dominates at 45%, followed by Ethereum at 30%)
- **Bottom Left**: Correlation heatmap between volatility and trading volume
- **Bottom Right**: Age group distribution of active traders

### What This Visualizes

**Key Insights:**

1. **Peak Trading Hours**: Singapore crypto traders are most active between 9-11 PM, coinciding with evening relaxation time after work

2. **Cryptocurrency Preferences**: 
   - Bitcoin: 45% of trading volume
   - Ethereum: 30% of trading volume
   - Solana: 15% of trading volume
   - Other altcoins: 10% of trading volume

3. **Volatility Correlation**: Strong positive correlation (r = 0.78) between price volatility and trading volume - traders are more active during volatile market conditions

4. **Demographic Patterns**: 
   - Highest activity in 25-34 age group (40%)
   - Second highest in 35-44 age group (30%)
   - Younger traders (18-24) show preference for smaller-cap altcoins

5. **Weekend Effect**: Trading volume increases by 35% on weekends compared to weekdays

### Design Choices

**Why I chose this visualization type:**

I used a **dashboard-style multi-panel layout** because:
- It allows comparison of multiple related metrics simultaneously
- Each panel tells a part of the overall story
- Viewers can identify patterns across different dimensions of the data

**Specific chart types:**
- **Line chart** for hourly trends: Best shows temporal patterns and peak hours
- **Pie chart** for cryptocurrency distribution: Clearly shows proportional market share
- **Heatmap** for correlations: Reveals relationships between variables at a glance
- **Stacked bar chart** for demographics: Shows both total volume and age distribution

**Color scheme:**
- **Blue gradient**: Represents trust and stability (appropriate for financial data)
- **Orange/Red**: Used for high volatility and peak activity (draws attention)
- **Green**: Positive price movements and growth metrics
- Consistent color palette across all panels for professional appearance

**Layout and formatting:**
- Clear axis labels with appropriate units (%, SGD, hours)
- Legend placed consistently in top-right of each panel
- Grid lines for easy value reading
- Annotations highlighting key insights

### The Story Behind This

**Context:**

This project was completed for my **DAT1001: Introduction to Data Analytics** module during Semester 1, Year 1. The assignment required us to:
- Identify a real-world dataset
- Perform exploratory data analysis
- Create meaningful visualizations
- Present actionable insights

**Challenges I Faced:**

1. **Data Cleaning**: The raw trading data had inconsistencies in timestamps and missing values (~5% of records). I used Python pandas to handle missing data through forward-fill for time-series continuity.

2. **Choosing the Right Visualization**: Initially, I tried cramming everything into a single chart, which looked cluttered. After feedback from my professor, I redesigned it as a multi-panel dashboard.

3. **Color Accessibility**: My first version used red-green colors, which I learned could be problematic for colorblind viewers. I switched to a blue-orange palette for better accessibility.

4. **Performance**: Rendering 50,000+ data points caused performance issues. I learned to aggregate data by hour instead of plotting every transaction.

**What I Learned:**

- The importance of data cleaning before visualization
- How to choose chart types that match the data story
- The power of multi-panel visualizations for complex datasets
- Accessibility considerations in data visualization design
- How to use Python libraries effectively for data analysis

### Technical Details

**Tools Used:**
- **Python 3.9**: Main programming language
- **pandas**: Data manipulation and aggregation
- **matplotlib & seaborn**: Visualization libraries
- **numpy**: Statistical calculations
- **Jupyter Notebook**: Interactive development environment

**Code Snippet:**
```python

title: Hackathon Experiences
text: Throughout my academic journey, I‚Äôve participated in several hackathons that have shaped my problem-solving abilities and technical skills. Here are my key hackathon experiences:

title: Hackathon Experiences
text:
VISA Fin-Connect Hackathon 2024 - Runner-Up ü•à

Project: Aura - AI-Powered Travel Rewards Platform
Achievement: Secured Runner-Up position in a competitive national hackathon
The Problem: Traditional credit card rewards programs fail to personalize benefits and help users maximize their spending potential.
Our Solution: We developed Aura, an innovative platform featuring:

1. Spend Futures - AI Spending Predictor

Machine learning model that analyzes historical spending patterns
Predicts future expenses across different categories
Provides personalized recommendations for optimal card usage



2. Gamified Challenges

Interactive challenges to encourage smart spending habits
Reward multipliers for achieving spending goals
Competitive leaderboards among friends



3. Personalized Rewards Engine

Real-time analysis of available credit card benefits
Smart suggestions based on upcoming purchases
Integration with VISA‚Äôs rewards ecosystem

Technologies Used: Python, React, Node.js, TensorFlow, VISA APIs
Key Takeaways: - Learned to develop under tight time constraints (24-48 hours) - Gained experience in FinTech API integration - Improved presentation and pitching skills - Understanding of the credit card rewards ecosystem

title: Hackathon Experiences
text:
HackRift 2025 - Finalist üèÜ

Project: Hasslefree - AI Multilingual Voice-Powered Documentation App
Achievement: Selected as one of the finalists among 100+ teams
The Problem: Healthcare documentation is time-consuming and often creates barriers for non-English speaking patients and doctors.
Our Solution: Hasslefree - A full-stack application that revolutionizes medical documentation:

Core Features
1. Voice-to-Text Documentation - Real-time speech recognition using MediaRecorder API - Instant conversion of doctor-patient conversations to structured notes - Hands-free operation for busy healthcare professionals
2. AI-Powered Intelligence - Integrated Grok API for intelligent summarization - Automatic extraction of key medical information - Context-aware suggestions and terminology correction
3. Multilingual Support - Real-time translation capabilities - Support for multiple languages and dialects - Breaking language barriers in healthcare
4. Edge Computing - Deployed on Edge Functions for ultra-low latency - Privacy-first architecture with local processing - HIPAA-compliant data handling


Technical Stack

Frontend: Next.js, React
Backend: Edge Functions (Vercel/Cloudflare)
AI Integration: Grok API
Audio Processing: MediaRecorder API, Web Speech API
Deployment: Edge network for global accessibility

Key Features: - Real-time voice transcription with <1s latency - Multi-speaker detection and attribution - Automatic medical terminology correction - Export to standard medical documentation formats
Impact: - Reduces documentation time by up to 70% - Improves accuracy in patient records - Enables better doctor-patient communication across language barriers - Scalable solution for healthcare facilities of all sizes
What I Learned: - Edge computing architecture and deployment - Real-time audio processing and streaming - LLM API integration and prompt engineering - Healthcare technology compliance considerations - Building accessible and inclusive applications

title: Data Visualization
text:
During my Data Analytics module in Year 1, I conducted an analysis of cryptocurrency trading patterns among Singapore investors. This project aimed to identify trends in trading behavior, popular cryptocurrencies, and correlations between market volatility and trading volume.



Dataset Details: - Source: Simulated trading data based on public cryptocurrency APIs (CoinGecko, Binance) - Variables: Trading volume, cryptocurrency type, time of day, price volatility, trader demographics - Time Period: January 2023 - December 2024 (24 months) - Size: 50,000+ transaction records from 1,200 simulated traders - Metrics: BTC, ETH, SOL, MATIC trading volumes, hourly price changes, trader age groups






Cryptocurrency Trading Patterns


Note: This is a multi-panel visualization showing: - Top Left: Trading volume by hour of day (shows peak activity at 9-10 PM SGT) - Top Right: Most traded cryptocurrencies (Bitcoin dominates at 45%, followed by Ethereum at 30%) - Bottom Left: Correlation heatmap between volatility and trading volume - Bottom Right: Age group distribution of active traders



Key Insights:

Peak Trading Hours: Singapore crypto traders are most active between 9-11 PM, coinciding with evening relaxation time after work
Cryptocurrency Preferences:

Bitcoin: 45% of trading volume
Ethereum: 30% of trading volume
Solana: 15% of trading volume
Other altcoins: 10% of trading volume

Volatility Correlation: Strong positive correlation (r = 0.78) between price volatility and trading volume - traders are more active during volatile market conditions
Demographic Patterns:

Highest activity in 25-34 age group (40%)
Second highest in 35-44 age group (30%)
Younger traders (18-24) show preference for smaller-cap altcoins

Weekend Effect: Trading volume increases by 35% on weekends compared to weekdays




Why I chose this visualization type:
I used a dashboard-style multi-panel layout because: - It allows comparison of multiple related metrics simultaneously - Each panel tells a part of the overall story - Viewers can identify patterns across different dimensions of the data
Specific chart types: - Line chart for hourly trends: Best shows temporal patterns and peak hours - Pie chart for cryptocurrency distribution: Clearly shows proportional market share - Heatmap for correlations: Reveals relationships between variables at a glance - Stacked bar chart for demographics: Shows both total volume and age distribution
Color scheme: - Blue gradient: Represents trust and stability (appropriate for financial data) - Orange/Red: Used for high volatility and peak activity (draws attention) - Green: Positive price movements and growth metrics - Consistent color palette across all panels for professional appearance
Layout and formatting: - Clear axis labels with appropriate units (%, SGD, hours) - Legend placed consistently in top-right of each panel - Grid lines for easy value reading - Annotations highlighting key insights



Context:
This project was completed for my DAT1001: Introduction to Data Analytics module during Semester 1, Year 1. The assignment required us to: - Identify a real-world dataset - Perform exploratory data analysis - Create meaningful visualizations - Present actionable insights
Challenges I Faced:

Data Cleaning: The raw trading data had inconsistencies in timestamps and missing values (~5% of records). I used Python pandas to handle missing data through forward-fill for time-series continuity.
Choosing the Right Visualization: Initially, I tried cramming everything into a single chart, which looked cluttered. After feedback from my professor, I redesigned it as a multi-panel dashboard.
Color Accessibility: My first version used red-green colors, which I learned could be problematic for colorblind viewers. I switched to a blue-orange palette for better accessibility.
Performance: Rendering 50,000+ data points caused performance issues. I learned to aggregate data by hour instead of plotting every transaction.

What I Learned:

The importance of data cleaning before visualization
How to choose chart types that match the data story
The power of multi-panel visualizations for complex datasets
Accessibility considerations in data visualization design
How to use Python libraries effectively for data analysis




Tools Used: - Python 3.9: Main programming language - pandas: Data manipulation and aggregation - matplotlib & seaborn: Visualization libraries - numpy: Statistical calculations - Jupyter Notebook: Interactive development environment

title: "Data Visualization"
---

## Singapore Cryptocurrency Trading Patterns Analysis (2023-2024)

### Overview

During my Data Analytics module in Year 1, I conducted an analysis of cryptocurrency trading patterns among Singapore investors. This project aimed to identify trends in trading behavior, popular cryptocurrencies, and correlations between market volatility and trading volume.

### The Data

**Dataset Details:**
- **Source**: Simulated trading data based on public cryptocurrency APIs (CoinGecko, Binance)
- **Variables**: Trading volume, cryptocurrency type, time of day, price volatility, trader demographics
- **Time Period**: January 2023 - December 2024 (24 months)
- **Size**: 50,000+ transaction records from 1,200 simulated traders
- **Metrics**: BTC, ETH, SOL, MATIC trading volumes, hourly price changes, trader age groups

### Visualization

![Cryptocurrency Trading Patterns](images/crypto_viz.png)

*Note: This is a multi-panel visualization showing:*
- **Top Left**: Trading volume by hour of day (shows peak activity at 9-10 PM SGT)
- **Top Right**: Most traded cryptocurrencies (Bitcoin dominates at 45%, followed by Ethereum at 30%)
- **Bottom Left**: Correlation heatmap between volatility and trading volume
- **Bottom Right**: Age group distribution of active traders

### What This Visualizes

**Key Insights:**

1. **Peak Trading Hours**: Singapore crypto traders are most active between 9-11 PM, coinciding with evening relaxation time after work

2. **Cryptocurrency Preferences**: 
   - Bitcoin: 45% of trading volume
   - Ethereum: 30% of trading volume
   - Solana: 15% of trading volume
   - Other altcoins: 10% of trading volume

3. **Volatility Correlation**: Strong positive correlation (r = 0.78) between price volatility and trading volume - traders are more active during volatile market conditions

4. **Demographic Patterns**: 
   - Highest activity in 25-34 age group (40%)
   - Second highest in 35-44 age group (30%)
   - Younger traders (18-24) show preference for smaller-cap altcoins

5. **Weekend Effect**: Trading volume increases by 35% on weekends compared to weekdays

### Design Choices

**Why I chose this visualization type:**

I used a **dashboard-style multi-panel layout** because:
- It allows comparison of multiple related metrics simultaneously
- Each panel tells a part of the overall story
- Viewers can identify patterns across different dimensions of the data

**Specific chart types:**
- **Line chart** for hourly trends: Best shows temporal patterns and peak hours
- **Pie chart** for cryptocurrency distribution: Clearly shows proportional market share
- **Heatmap** for correlations: Reveals relationships between variables at a glance
- **Stacked bar chart** for demographics: Shows both total volume and age distribution

**Color scheme:**
- **Blue gradient**: Represents trust and stability (appropriate for financial data)
- **Orange/Red**: Used for high volatility and peak activity (draws attention)
- **Green**: Positive price movements and growth metrics
- Consistent color palette across all panels for professional appearance

**Layout and formatting:**
- Clear axis labels with appropriate units (%, SGD, hours)
- Legend placed consistently in top-right of each panel
- Grid lines for easy value reading
- Annotations highlighting key insights

### The Story Behind This

**Context:**

This project was completed for my **DAT1001: Introduction to Data Analytics** module during Semester 1, Year 1. The assignment required us to:
- Identify a real-world dataset
- Perform exploratory data analysis
- Create meaningful visualizations
- Present actionable insights

**Challenges I Faced:**

1. **Data Cleaning**: The raw trading data had inconsistencies in timestamps and missing values (~5% of records). I used Python pandas to handle missing data through forward-fill for time-series continuity.

2. **Choosing the Right Visualization**: Initially, I tried cramming everything into a single chart, which looked cluttered. After feedback from my professor, I redesigned it as a multi-panel dashboard.

3. **Color Accessibility**: My first version used red-green colors, which I learned could be problematic for colorblind viewers. I switched to a blue-orange palette for better accessibility.

4. **Performance**: Rendering 50,000+ data points caused performance issues. I learned to aggregate data by hour instead of plotting every transaction.

**What I Learned:**

- The importance of data cleaning before visualization
- How to choose chart types that match the data story
- The power of multi-panel visualizations for complex datasets
- Accessibility considerations in data visualization design
- How to use Python libraries effectively for data analysis

### Technical Details

**Tools Used:**
- **Python 3.9**: Main programming language
- **pandas**: Data manipulation and aggregation
- **matplotlib & seaborn**: Visualization libraries
- **numpy**: Statistical calculations
- **Jupyter Notebook**: Interactive development environment

**Code Snippet:**
```python

title: About Matthew Tan
text:
üåü Personal Philosophy


On Learning üìö

‚ÄúI believe in continuous learning and staying curious. Technology evolves rapidly, and the key to staying relevant is maintaining a growth mindset. Whether it‚Äôs a new programming language, framework, or domain knowledge, I‚Äôm always eager to expand my skill set.‚Äù



On Problem-Solving üß©

‚ÄúEvery problem is an opportunity to learn. I approach challenges systematically: understand the problem deeply, break it down into manageable parts, research solutions, implement iteratively, and always reflect on what could be improved.‚Äù



On Collaboration ü§ù

‚ÄúThe best solutions come from diverse perspectives. I value teamwork and believe that effective communication is just as important as technical skills. Teaching has reinforced this - explaining complex ideas clearly makes you a better developer.‚Äù



On Impact üéØ

üé¨ Featured: My Most Recent Hackathon
